# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Here is a Julia function that solves the task:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # Filter the DataFrame for rows with manufacturer "audi" and model being "a4" or "a4 quattro"
    df_filtered = filter(row -> row[:manufacturer] == "audi" && (row[:model] == "a4" || row[:model] == "a4 quattro"), df)
    
    # Create a new column `audi_a4_type` and set it to true for all rows
    insertcols!(df_filtered, :audi_a4_type => trues(nrow(df_filtered)))
    
    return df_filtered
end

# Test the function with example data
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
filtered_df = audi_filter(df_cars)
```

This function first filters the input DataFrame to only include rows where the manufacturer is Audi and the model is either an a4 or an a4 quattro. Then, it creates a new column `audi_a4_type` and sets it to true for every row in the filtered DataFrame before returning it.
